diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +6,10 @@#' @param uri A directory containing modeling scripts, defaults to the current directory.
#' @param version Version of the project to run, as a Git commit reference for Git projects.
#' @param parameters A list of parameters.
#' @param experiment_id ID of the experiment under which to launch the run.
#' @param experiment_name Name of the experiment under which to launch the run.

comments.body: Switched the order of `entry_point` and `uri` to match Python ([link](https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/a1168a35f68643cbf3ef17411ee53d9ef2e08c7e/mlflow/projects/__init__.py#L153))
We'll want to make a note of this since it breaks `mlflow_run("stuff.R")` which is a common use case.

Does it? I thought you can do 
```
mlflow run path/to/stuff.R

^Yep, using the CLI should still work since it invokes `Rscript -e /path/to/script.R`, but yeah we need to document that users should change R code like `mlflow_run("/path/to/script.R)` to `mlflow_run(entry_point = "/path/to/script.R")` (e.g. for R users who are calling `mlflow_run` to run a single script in the current directory). Would mentioning this in release notes / the MLflow 1.0 migration guide suffice?
I think that's ok, thanks for the clarification Sid!

Yep that's exactly it. It might be worth an informative error message if the user passes a `.py` or `.R` file first. Do you guys think it makes sense to have this at the python level or just in the R function?
I think we should have it at the python level. Hopefully it would propagate nicely back to R.

                       no_conda = FALSE, storage_dir = NULL) {
